title: Read - a typeface designed for dyslexia
content:
the text below is part of a feature profiling young british designers in yesterday's [observer](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123007/http:/observer.guardian.co.uk/magazine/story/0%2C11913%2C1061039%2C00.html).

> * * *
> **quote:**
> 
> Natascha Frensch, 27   
> Can a new typeface help people with dyslexia read and write more effectively? Britain has 2m severe dyslexics, including 375,000 schoolchildren. Frensch has designed Read, a sans serif typeface she hopes will help people to read and write more clearly. It works because each letter is drawn individually. She has produced a limited edition book that explains how she did it and why and hopes to sell the typeface via a website, [www.readregular.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123007/http:/www.readregular.com/) (which has yet to be set up). For individuals, it will be 'the price of a CD', while bigger corporations will have to pay accordingly. There is also a version for children. Email contact: [natascha.frensch@readregular.com](mailto:natascha.frensch@readregular.com)
> 
> * * *  
   
 [http://www.readregular.com/english/intro.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123007/http:/www.readregular.com/english/intro.html)

[i originally posted the above links in 'news & events' but, as its been pointed out to me, the story seems ripe for typophile comment. take it away...]
author: geraintf

comments.content: The 'background' section of the readregular.com website focuses on letter differentiation and simplicity, but the section on dyslexia doesn't actually indicate how dyslexia relates to letter confusion. What is the relationship?

My main problem with it is that it's way too conservative.
